questions.question_text: An engineer must configure Cisco ACI for VMM integration to VMware vCenter. Which two attributes must be configured on the Cisco APIC to achieve this goal? (Choose two.)

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: AE
To integrate Cisco ACI with VMware vCenter, the following attributes must be configured on the Cisco APIC:
Cluster Name (A):
The cluster name refers to the vCenter server object that needs to be created in the APIC. This includes specifying the name of the vCenter server and associating it with the VMM domain.
Logon Credentials (E):
The APIC requires administrator-level credentials (username and password) to authenticate and connect to the VMware vCenter. These credentials are used to establish communication between Cisco ACI and vCenter.
These two attributes, cluster name and logon credentials, are essential for establishing a connection between Cisco ACI and VMware vCenter, enabling seamless integration and management of virtualized environments.

Selected Answer: BE
Data Center name is specified in Create vCenter Controller screen

The lo0 interface with its assigned IP address acts as the VXLAN Tunnel Endpoint (VTEP), enabling VXLAN encapsulation within the ACI fabric. Thus, the answer is B. Fabric.

The loopback interface (lo0) is the VTEP, not the PTEP. The PTEP refers to the physical interfaces (e.g., eth1/49, eth1/50) that carry VXLAN traffic over the fabric underlay.

 • PTEP: The physical interface on which VXLAN traffic flows.
 • VTEP (lo0): The logical representation of the VXLAN endpoint, using the loopback interface for encapsulation/decapsulation.

The user can extend an EPG beyond an ACI leaf by statically assigning a leaf port (along with a VLAN ID) to an EPG. After doing so, all the traffic received on this leaf port with the configured VLAN ID will be mapped to the EPG and the configured policy for this EPG will be enforced. The endpoints need not be directly connected to the ACI leaf port. They can be behind a layer 2 network as long as the VLAN associated with the EPG is enabled within the layer 2 network that connects the remote endpoint to the ACI fabric.

questions.question_text: A Cisco ACI fabric must send a packet between two pods in a Cisco ACI Multi-Pod topology where ARP flooding is disabled within the bridge domain. How does a Cisco ACI spine switch forward ARP messages from a leaf switch in POD1 to POD2?

choices.B: The ARP message is dropped and connectivity is lost between the endpoints.
choices.A: ARP optimization is applied and sends ARP to remote anycast.
choices.C: A proxy ARP message is sent to destination group 225.224.0.0.
choices.D: An ARP Glean message is sent to multicast address 239.255.255.240.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: D
In a Cisco ACI fabric, ARP Glean messages are sent to a specific multicast group address associated with the bridge domain (BD) when ARP flooding is disabled.

Selected Answer: D
Agree with mms101. The option A is for the leaf, while D is for the spine

D
"Without ARP flooding allowed in the Bridge Domain, the leaf nodes are not allowed to flood the frame along the local multi-destination tree, so in order to ensure the ARP request can be delivered to a remote endpoint for allowing its discovery, a process named “ARP Gleaning” has been implemented."
https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/solutions/collateral/data-center-virtualization/application-centric-infrastructure/white-paper-c11-737855.html#:~:text=Without%20ARP%20flooding%20allowed%20in%20the%20Bridge%20Domain%2C%20the%20leaf%20nodes%20are%20not%20allowed%20to%20flood%20the%20frame%20along%20the%20local%20multi%2Ddestination%20tree%2C%20so%20in%20order%20to%20ensure%20the%20ARP%20request%20can%20be%20delivered%20to%20a%20remote%20endpoint%20for%20allowing%20its%20discovery%2C%20a%20process%20named%20%E2%80%9CARP%20Gleaning%E2%80%9D%20has%20been%20implemented.
